I’m proud to have co-sponsored the Menstrual Equity for All Act & to have reintroduced, for the 11th time, the Robin Danielson Feminine Hygiene Safety Act. I vow to advocate for the #MensturationMovement today and every day!

Menstrual health care products should not be treated as luxury items, and access should be considered a health right. Millions use products like tampons & pads, yet 34 states still tax them! We must end the #TamponTax and fight back.

2 out of 3 low-income people in major US cities reported being unable to afford menstrual products last year. #PeriodPoverty is real and impacts individuals experiencing homelessness, and those who are low-income, trans, and incarcerated the most. This is an injustice.

Today is #NationalPeriodDay! People are rallying across the country to finally end the stigma surrounding #MenstrualEquity & fight for access to free, healthy menstrual hygiene products. Nobody should have to choose between buying food or period products. #ME4ALL #PeriodPower

I'm also proud to share that this year, the Senate has announced plans to increase funding for targeted #Alzheimers research by $350 million in 2020. As a country, we have a lot of tough decisions ahead – but choosing to invest in research to lead us to a cure isn't one of them.

I've cosponsored several important bills, like the Younger-Onset Alzheimer's Disease Act and the Improving HOPE for Alzheimer's Act. Just last year, I was proud to see the BOLD Infrastructure for #Alzheimers Act signed into law.

With the population of older Americans growing at a rapid pace, there has never been a more crucial time to fight for a cure for #Alzheimers. I have and will continue this fight both at home in Delaware and as a senator in Washington.

Earlier this year, I had the privilege of meeting with a large group of Delawareans who came to Washington to remind me how far we've come in our efforts to find a cure for #Alzheimers, and how far we've yet to go.
Though our understanding of #Alzheimers has progressed remarkably over the last 20 years, there's still no known cure or treatment capable of delaying its progression.

More than five million Americans, including nearly 20,000 Delawareans, are living with #Alzheimers, and another 55,000 Delawareans are caring for someone with the disease. Alzheimer's is devastating and has stolen too many Americans from their loved ones.

Thank you to the volunteers, walkers, and sponsors who supported today's Walk to End Alzheimer's. They were here on behalf of thousands of Delawareans living with this devastating disease.
